In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of Mongolia requested policy and advisory technical assistance (TA) 
from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) for Developing a Conducive Environment for Public–
Private Partnerships (PPPs). Following a reconnaissance mission to Ulaanbaatar during 10–14 
September 2012 and a fact-finding mission on 19 October 2012, ADB and the government 
reached an understanding on the objectives, scope, implementation arrangement, costs, and 
terms of reference for the TA. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.1 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  A lack of infrastructure in many places and rapidly deteriorating infrastructure in others 
undermine  Mongolia’s  competitiveness.  The  government  has  identified  PPPs  as  a  way  to 
accelerate development by improving infrastructure and, more broadly, the delivery of public 
services. Important steps have been taken in recent years to establish the enabling environment 
needed for successful PPPs. 
 
3.  In  2009,  Parliament  adopted  a  state  policy  on  PPPs,  which  comprises  a  set  of 
resolutions  that  established  the  principles  governing  PPPs.  It  covers  (i)  the  stages  of 
implementation, (ii) the types of PPP arrangements to be utilized, (iii) the legal framework, and 
(iv) project management. In 2010, Parliament adopted the Law on Concessions to regulate the 
tendering process and define the rights and obligations of PPP participants in a practical, 
transparent fashion. The law was crafted in line with global best practice to lower risk, instill 
confidence, and improve the investment climate for PPPs. It also laid out the responsibilities and 
powers of the Department of Public–Private Partnerships and Concessions (PPP Unit) within 
the State Property Committee. The unit became operational in 2011. 
 
4.  Continued strengthening is needed to realize the potential contribution from PPPs. A 
2011 regional study of the enabling environment for PPPs ranked Mongolia in the “nascent” 
category of countries.2 The study, supported by ADB, noted that the enabling environment for 
PPPs was weakened by (i) the absence of a completed PPP since 2001; (ii) gaps in the legal 
and regulatory framework; (iii) below-market prices for energy, water, and transport; (iv) a lack 
of  the  expertise  needed  to  design  and  implement  PPPs;  and  (v)  underdeveloped  capital 
markets. The study acknowledged the importance of the Concessions Law and the PPP Unit as 
initial steps to improving the enabling environment for PPPs, but concluded that additional 
capacity building and reform is required.  
 
5.  The government’s action plan for 2012–2016 commits to a heightened role for  PPPs.3 In 
a recent restructuring of agencies under the new government, the functions of the PPP Unit 
were  transferred  from  the  State  Property  Committee  to  the  Innovation  and  Public–Private 
Partnerships (IPPP) Department in the new Ministry of Economic Development (MED). The 
government’s  investment  and  planning  functions  have  been  consolidated  under  MED  to 
streamline and coordinate medium- and long-term strategic planning. The IPPP Department and 
the Development Policy and Strategic Planning (DPSP) Department, which has taken over the 
role of the former National Development and Innovation Committee, will form the institutional 
pillars of infrastructure planning in the new government. Thus, the restructuring elevated the

authority of the PPP Unit among line ministries, which will assist its facilitation of PPPs.4 Public 
policy  discussion  continues  to  feature  PPPs,  and  policy  makers  have  demonstrated  an 
understanding of the potential offered by working with the private sector. 
 
6.  The  preparation  of  pathfinder  PPPs  is  complementing  efforts  to  improve  the 
management of PPPs within the government. The government has prepared a list of candidate 
PPPs, and development partners have been helping prepare priority PPPs. In June 2011, ADB 
was appointed to advise the government in structuring the PPP for the Combined Heat and 
Power Plant Number 5 on a build-operate-transfer basis.5 The plant is to meet the growing 
energy demand resulting from rapid urbanization and economic development; it will also reduce 
urban air pollution by retiring older, less efficient plants.6 The project illustrates the potential for 
PPPs to bring in a high-quality, experienced operator to share project risk and to mobilize 
additional  financial  resources.  International  investors  are  closely  watching  this  and  other 
pathfinder projects as an indicator of Mongolia’s readiness for PPPs. 
 
7.  In  addition  to  assisting  on  this  major  pathfinder  PPP,  ADB  has  made  important 
contributions  to  the  development  of  the  enabling  environment.  The  first  phase  of  ADB 
assistance helped develop the core of the legal and institutional framework for PPPs, and 
contributed to the development of the Concessions Law and the establishment of the PPP Unit.7 
The second phase strengthened the capacity of the PPP Unit and supported the preparation of 
a  PPP  handbook  to  explain  how  the  government  can  identify  PPP  projects,  structure  the 
projects, procure them, and monitor and enforce the PPP arrangements. The TA also supported 
the preparation of a workbook for the PPP Unit and facilitated outreach to line ministries and the 
firming up of the PPP project pipeline.8  
 
8.  ADB’s country partnership strategy for Mongolia, 2012–2016 aims to achieve inclusive 
and sustainable growth.9 Support for PPPs will assist by bringing in private financing for the 
infrastructure needed to improve access to essential public services in transport, energy, and 
water  supply,  as  well  as  other  municipal  infrastructure.  This  will  ease  bottlenecks  in  the 
economy, resulting in more equitable and efficient growth. Private sector development, which is 
expected to play a significant role in achieving the strategic objectives of the government and 
ADB, will be fostered through support for PPPs.  
 
9.  Mongolia needs assistance to continue strengthening its legal, policy, and institutional 
framework in order to develop a conducive environment for PPPs. The priorities are to (i) update 
the framework for the recent government restructuring, (ii) pursue refinements to the PPP 
legislation, (iii) improve the integration of PPP preparation with public investment planning, and 
(iv) build the capacity of MED staff. The preparation of new PPPs also needs to be initiated in 
order to meet urgent development needs, particularly in the capital, Ulaanbaatar City. Such 
assistance will contribute to the finalization of pathfinder PPPs, including the Combined Heat 
and Power Plant Number 5, and raise Mongolia’s profile among international investors.

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome  
 
10.  The impact of the TA will be the delivery of improved public services to poorly serviced 
populations. The outcome of the TA will be a stronger human resource base and institutional, 
legal, and regulatory framework for PPPs. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities  
 
11.  The TA will harmonize the legal and regulatory framework and planning process for 
PPPs with recent changes in the government structure, and build the capacity of government 
staff to operate in this improved framework. Support will also be provided for prescreening 
priority  PPPs  and  preparing  terms  of reference for transaction  advisory  services. This  will 
advance  the  PPP  pipeline  and  build  the  capacity  of  MED  through  a  “learning-by-doing” 
approach. 
 
12.  Recommendations for strengthening the legal and regulatory framework for PPPs will be 
prepared.  The  TA  will  review  the  legal  and  regulatory  amendments  recommended  under 
previous TA projects and by other development partners. The laws that will be considered for 
review  include  the  Concessions  Law,  the  Budget  Law,  the  Government’s  Procurement 
Guidelines, and relevant sector laws. A desirable long-term evolution of the legal and regulatory 
framework will be mapped out, which will include an implementation time line that distinguishes 
between measures warranting immediate adoption and those of a longer-term nature. Based on 
the review of previous recommendations and feedback from private and public stakeholders, the 
TA will draft and then assist in the adoption of amendments to the Concessions Law and other 
laws. 
 
13.  The TA will help prepare guidelines that update the procedures for PPP planning and 
identification in order to integrate the PPP and public investment planning processes. This will 
include preparation of an interdepartmental planning schedule with an indicative time line and a 
clearer allocation of responsibilities between departments, and the development of a detailed 
process flowchart. Specific items to be addressed include (i) coordination with line ministries for 
developing and prioritizing PPP projects, (ii) the development and application of PPP screening 
criteria, and (iii) coordination with the DPSP Department on the additional analysis required to 
assess project feasibility. The TA will support learning-by-doing by helping the IPPP and DPSP 
departments work through implementation of one planning cycle as a capacity building exercise. 
 
14.  The capacity development of MED staff will emphasize the IPPP Department. Drawing 
on an assessment of staff capacity and needs, a training curriculum will be developed for the 
IPPP Department staff. This will develop their skills in risk analysis, risk allocation, financial and 
economic  analysis,  value-for-money  assessment,  contingent  liability  valuation,  and  sector-
specific issues relevant to priority PPPs. The TA will utilize and update material prepared under 
previous TA projects and will ensure coordination with MED’s ongoing training on PPP issues 
with Singapore International Enterprise. The TA will include staff of other MED departments and 
government agencies in capacity development exercises relevant to their work.  
 
15.  The TA will also fund the prescreening of priority PPPs. The PPP handbook identifies 
the steps required to prepare a PPP. It provides for a prescreening of PPPs before feasibility 
studies are conducted and transaction advisers are appointed. The prescreening process will 
assess whether a project is likely to deliver value for money by considering the scale of a

4   
project,  the  specificity  of  the  outputs,  risk  transfer  opportunities,  the  likelihood  of  financial 
viability and market interest in the project, and affordability for the government. The TA will be 
open to funding the prescreening of projects where government ownership and expected project 
viability are high. The terms of reference for transaction advisory services will be prepared for 
the prescreened PPPs that are to proceed. 
 
16.  The success of the TA in building the human resource base will be determined by 
whether the staff of the IPPP Department have independently completed the prescreening of an 
additional, simple PPP by completion of the TA project. 
 
17.  The TA will support targeted workshops and seminars to raise awareness among line 
ministries and other government stakeholders at various stages of TA implementation, and to 
disseminate findings and gather feedback on TA activities. Knowledge products will also be 
prepared in the form of short policy and technical notes. 
 
18.  The TA assumes that international investors remain open to engagement in PPPs in 
emerging markets, and that the government’s support for PPPs continues. It also assumes that 
MED staff remain committed to developing PPPs and building their capacity in PPPs, and that 
the ministry can obtain and retain sufficient human resources. The key risk is that political 
uncertainty may slow decision making on institutional, legal, and regulatory reforms. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing  
 
19.  The TA is estimated to cost $800,000, of which $750,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis from ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund IV (TASF-IV). The government will provide 
counterpart support in the form of office space, counterpart staff, and other services to the 
consultants; and will assist in arranging meetings with counterpart agencies. The cost estimates 
and financing plan are in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements  
 
20.  MED will be the executing and implementing agency for the TA. The IPPP Department 
within MED will provide overall guidance to the TA and be responsible for coordination. The TA 
will work closely with MED’s DPSP Department to integrate PPP planning into public investment 
planning.  
 
21.  A team of international consultants will be engaged for up to 12 person-months. It will 
include  a  team  leader  and  PPP  institutional  adviser,  a  PPP  legal  adviser,  a  capacity 
development adviser, and PPP expert(s). National consultants will be engaged for up to 51 
person-months.  They  will  include  a  deputy  team  leader,  a  legal  specialist,  a  capacity 
development  specialist,  and  technical  specialist(s).  The  outline  terms  of  reference  are  in 
Appendix 3. 
 
22.  The consultants will be recruited individually to ensure flexibility and timeliness. ADB will 
engage  the  international  and  national  consultants,  as  well  as  any  resource  persons,  in 
accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). 
Procurement of equipment, if any, will follow ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended 
from time to time). The proceeds of the TA will be disbursed in accordance with the Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010 as amended from time to time).

5 
23.  The TA will be implemented over 24 months, from 1 January 2013 until 30 December 
2014. Support for the strengthening of the legal and regulatory framework, the integration of the 
PPP  and  public  investment  planning  processes,  and  capacity  building  will  take  place 
concurrently. The initial assessment of institutional structures and knowledge gaps will occur 
within the first 3 months, with the implementation of required follow-on actions planned over the 
remainder of the TA period. The development of recommendations for amendments to the legal 
and  regulatory  framework  will  take  place  within  the  first  half  of  the  TA,  with  a  view  to 
implementing  the  immediate  priorities  over  the  second  half  of  the  TA.  Prescreening 
assessments of priority PPPs will be completed within the first 18 months of the TA. 
 
24.  The TA will be monitored and evaluated based on the implementation of activities and 
satisfactory delivery of outputs following the agreed time line and budget allocation. To support 
monitoring  and  evaluation,  the  consultant  team  will  submit  an  inception  report,  quarterly 
progress notes, a midterm report, a draft final report, and a final report to the government and 
ADB. The main mechanism to monitor progress, assess performance, and ensure relevance, 
will be TA review missions. All knowledge products and services created by the TA will be 
provided to MED and ADB for dissemination to the government and, as appropriate, other 
stakeholders. 
 
25.  The TA  will  be  implemented  in  close coordination  with  other  development  partners 
supporting  PPPs  and  public  investment  in  Mongolia,  including  German  International 
Cooperation,  the  International  Finance  Corporation,  the  Japan  International  Cooperation 
Agency,  and  the  World  Bank.  Outreach  activities  will  help  ensure  understanding  and 
engagement of these partners. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION  
26.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $750,000 on a grant basis to 
the  Government  of  Mongolia  for  Developing  a  Conducive  Environment  for  Public–Private 
Partnerships, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Overview 
 
1.  The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  will  individually  select  and  engage  up  to  six 
international consultants and six national consultants in accordance with its Guidelines on the 
Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
2.  Reporting  to  the  Ministry  of  Economic  Development  (MED)  and  the  ADB  task 
manager(s), the consultants will be required to provide deliverables consistent with the design 
and  monitoring  framework  (DMF)  activities,  outputs,  and  delivery  dates;  and  ensure  that 
technical assistance (TA) activities are implemented effectively and efficiently. Reports are to be 
of high quality and produced in English, with key material also produced in Mongolian. Precise 
reporting arrangements and time lines will be defined at inception and agreed upon with MED 
and ADB. The outline terms of reference will be refined before consultant recruitment. 
 
3.  MED will consult with the TA consultants frequently to ensure a clear understanding of 
the ministry’s needs and expectations, and to ensure that MED has an understanding of the 
activities being undertaken under the TA. Key stakeholders will be consulted to ensure their 
effective participation in the preparation of the TA outputs. This will include the circulation 
among  stakeholders  of  key  materials  produced,  and  the  coordination  of  a  workshop  with 
government stakeholders and relevant development partners to present the key findings and 
lessons of the TA. 
 
B.  Terms of Reference 
 
1.  International Consultants 
 
a.  Team Leader and Public–Private Partnership Institutional Specialist (5 
person-months, intermittent) 
 
4.  The team leader and public–private partnership (PPP) institutional specialist will have a 
post-graduate degree in economics, law, management, public policy, international development, 
or  a  closely  related  field,  as  well  as  at  least  10  years  experience  in  helping  government 
agencies develop an enabling environment for PPPs, and preparing and implementing PPP 
projects. Previous experience in the region (Central Asia, West Asia, or East Asia) is desirable. 
 
5.  The team leader will have overall responsibility within the consulting team for ensuring 
the delivery of the TA outputs, and activities through a government-led process that ensures 
local ownership of the TA. The responsibilities will include 
(i)  developing  and  implementing  the  TA  under  the  guidance  of  MED,  including 
coordination, capacity development and training, communication, and information 
sharing and dialogue with senior members of government and stakeholders; and 
establishing  reporting  arrangements  to  MED  and  ensuring  they  are  followed 
throughout the TA; 
(ii)  supporting MED in establishing an effective communication system that will raise 
awareness among the government and external stakeholders of PPPs, including 
through  seminars,  workshops,  and  preparing  knowledge  products  and  other 
information releases;

(iii)  transferring skills and building the capacity of staff of MED and other government 
agencies in PPPs; 
(iv)  assisting MED in the identification of priority PPPs to undergo a prescreening, 
and assisting in the preparation of terms of reference for transaction advisory 
services for the prescreened PPPs that are to proceed; 
(v)  developing operational guidelines and procedures for MED to identify, prioritize, 
and plan PPPs in a manner integrated with public investment planning, including 
the following: 
(a)  review of recommendations by previous TA to the PPP Unit within the 
State Property Committee; 
(b)  review of all laws and regulations that may govern the planning process 
and the process of developing PPPs; 
(c)  review  of  the  current  internal  procedures  within  MED,  particularly 
interactions between the Innovations and PPP (IPPP) Department and 
the Development Policy and Strategic Planning (DPSP) Department, and 
between these departments and other government agencies; 
(d)  development of an internal operations manual to guide the development 
of  PPPs  as  they  relate  to  the  overall  planning  process  within  MED, 
including  developing  a  clear  set  of  guidelines  and  procedures  for 
identifying infrastructure projects as possible PPPs, prioritizing PPPs, and 
identifying which of the high-priority projects should be developed for 
transactions and when; 
(e)  work with legal specialists in the IPPP Department to draft any regulations, 
decrees, or orders that formalize the procedures for PPP identification 
and prioritization; 
(f)  update the PPP Manual (developed under previous ADB TA) to reflect the 
recommended planning process; and 
(g)  provide training to IPPP and DPSP Department staff on their roles and 
responsibilities in developing PPPs within the overall planning process in 
MED. 
 
6.  In leading the TA implementation in accordance with the terms and conditions specified 
in the agreement between the government and ADB, the team leader will 
(i)  coordinate and manage the inputs, activities, and outputs of the TA consultants, 
including the allocation of responsibilities between consultants, and monitoring 
the performance of all consultants to achieve the results sought by the DMF, 
including initiating and leading discussions of key implementation issues with the 
government and managing TA quality control and quality assurance;  
(ii)  organize TA inception and concluding workshops with senior representatives of 
the government, government officials, and other relevant stakeholders to inform 
the preparation and/or review of the TA; 
(iii)  prepare and monitor progress against a risk management plan that will identify 
key risks to sustainability and the actions required to minimize these risks;  
(iv)  ensure  timely  preparation  and  submission  of  the  inception  report,  quarterly 
progress notes, the midterm report, and the final report; and assist with TA 
reviews undertaken by ADB and the government; and 
(v)  consult with development partners on TA activities, ensuring that development 
partners are frequently informed of activities and that a high level of coordination 
is maintained to avoid duplication or overlap of work.

12  Appendix 3 
 
 
b.  Public–Private Partnership Legal Adviser (2 person-months, intermittent) 
 
7.  The PPP legal adviser will be a lawyer with experience drafting PPP laws and working 
on PPP transactions. Previous experience in the region (Central Asia, West Asia, or East Asia) 
is desirable. The responsibilities of the consultant will include the following: 
(i)  reviewing recommendations of previous ADB TA on changes to the legal and 
regulatory framework for PPPs; 
(ii)  developing draft amendments to the Concessions Law based on a review of 
previous work and feedback from public and private stakeholders; 
(iii)  reviewing sector legislation and other supporting legislation (for example, related 
to  general  government  procurement)  to  assess  the  consistency  with  the 
Concessions Law; 
(iv)  recommending changes to sector legislation or other supporting legislation to 
harmonize it with the Concessions Law, including a recommended time line for 
implementation; and 
(v)  supporting the head of the IPPP Department in raising awareness of the legal 
and regulatory amendments proposed and their importance in improving the 
enabling environment for PPPs. 
 
c.  Capacity Development Adviser (2 person-months, intermittent) 
 
8.  The capacity development adviser will have a post-graduate degree in management, 
public policy, or a closely related field, as well as at least 10 years experience in capacity 
development in the public or private sectors. Previous experience with PPPs and within the 
region (Central Asia, West Asia, or East Asia) is desirable. The responsibilities of the consultant 
will include supporting the development of internal capacity in PPPs as follows: 
(i)  assess the capacity of MED staff to facilitate PPPs, and identify knowledge gaps 
and capacity weaknesses of MED, with an emphasis on the IPPP Department;  
(ii)  develop a detailed capacity building plan for MED, with an emphasis on the IPPP 
Department, including estimates of the budget needed to deliver the training 
required, which may include risk analysis and allocation, financial and economic 
analysis, a value-for-money assessment, and a contingent liability valuation; 
(iii)  liaise  with  development  partners  to  identify  possible  funding  for  training  not 
funded under the TA, and further develop the twinning arrangements initiated 
under previous ADB TA; 
(iv)  developing and deliver targeted training courses to staff of the IPPP Department 
and DPSP Department; 
(v)  identify the training needs of the DPSP and other MED departments as they 
relate to PPPs; 
(vi)  identify the training needs of other national and local government agencies with 
respect to PPPs, including the need to be trained on the planning procedures; 
and 
(vii)  train IPPP Department staff as trainers who can lead capacity building for other 
MED departments and other government agencies. 
 
d. Public–Private Partnership Specialist(s) (up to 3 positions, 1 person-month, 
intermittent) 
 
9.  The PPP specialist(s) will have a post-graduate degree in economics, law, management, 
public policy, international development, engineering, or a closely related field, and at least 10

Appendix 3  13 
years  experience  in  helping  government  agencies  prepare  and  implement  PPP  projects. 
Previous experience in the region (Central Asia, West Asia, or East Asia) is desirable. The PPP 
specialist(s) will undertake a prescreening assessment of priority PPPs in accordance with 
MED’s  PPP  handbook;  consult  with  key  government  stakeholders  on  the  findings  of  the 
prescreening assessment; and, as agreed with MED, present the pre-screening assessment to 
a workshop involving a wide range of stakeholders, including development partners. 
 
2.  National Consultants 
 
10.  National consultants will work with government counterparts on the implementation of 
the recommendations of the TA, research and compile relevant documents and information, 
translate documents, organize workshops and other events, and provide administrative and 
logistical support. The national consultants will be supervised by the international consultants 
and ADB task manager(s). 
 
a.  Deputy Team Leader (1 person, 24 person-months, full time) 
 
11.  The deputy team leader will have a degree in economics, law, management, public 
policy, international development, engineering, or a closely related field, as well as at least 10 
years experience in helping government agencies prepare and implement investment projects. 
The deputy team leader will support the team leader and PPP institutional specialist across all 
her or his roles and responsibilities, and coordinate the input of other national consultants on a 
day-to-day basis. Special emphasis will be paid to the development of procedures for identifying, 
prioritizing, and planning PPPs, and developing the IPPP Department’s internal capacity. The 
deputy team leader will also report to the director of the IPPP Department, supporting him or her 
in tasks related to the work of identifying, prioritizing, and planning PPPs, and developing 
internal capacity. 
 
b.  Legal Specialist (1 position, 12 person-months, intermittent) 
 
12.  The  national  legal  specialist  will  have  a  law  degree  and  experience  in  civil  and 
commercial law in Mongolia, as well at least 8 years drafting experience. The national legal 
specialist will help the international PPP legal adviser review the concessions Law, sector laws, 
and other supporting laws, and draft amendments to these laws in Mongolian. The national legal 
specialist will also work with the international PPP legal adviser to support MED in raising 
awareness of the legal and regulatory amendments proposed and their importance in improving 
the enabling environment for PPPs, and ensuring the implementation of the recommendations 
for improving the legal and regulatory framework. 
 
c.  Capacity  Development  Specialist  (1  position,  12  person-months, 
intermittent) 
 
13.  The capacity development specialist will have a degree in management, public policy, or 
a closely related field, as well as at least 5 years experience in capacity development in the 
public or private sectors. The capacity development specialist will help the international capacity 
development adviser across all her or his roles and responsibilities. 
 
d.  Technical Specialist (up to 3 positions, 1 person-month, intermittent) 
 
14.  The technical specialist will have a degree in economics, law, management, public policy, 
international development, engineering, or a closely related field, as well as at least 5 years

14  Appendix 3 
 
 
experience in helping government agencies prepare and implement investment projects. The 
national  technical  specialist  will  help  the  international  PPP  specialist(s)  undertake  a 
prescreening assessment of priority PPPs. 
 
C.  Reporting Requirements 
15.  The  team  leader  will  be  responsible  for  ensuring  that  all  reports,  documents,  and 
submissions produced under the TA will be of publishable and high professional standard. All 
reports required to document and assess TA activities are to be in English and suitable. With 
the support of TA consultants, the team leader will submit the following:  
(i)  Inception report. This report will provide a clear plan for implementing the TA, 
challenges to its success, and a summary of the status of TA performance. It will, 
to the extent feasible, provide (a) confirmation of the overall TA rationale and 
design, or (b) adjustments recommended to improve TA performance, including 
to the terms of reference of consultants, and (c) a detailed TA implementation 
schedule. 
(ii)  Quarterly  progress  notes.  These  brief  notes  (maximum  of  five  pages)  will 
inform the government and ADB of the status of TA implementation. 
(iii)  Midterm report. This report will inform the government and ADB of the status of 
implementing the terms of reference, plans for achieving the TA objectives, and a 
personnel schedule with accomplishments under each item of the DMF. This 
report will record activities, outputs, and outcomes directly against the TA’s DMF. 
It will provide (a) confirmation of the TA overall rationale and design, or (b) 
adjustments recommended to improve TA performance, including to the terms of 
reference of consultants, and (c) a detailed TA implementation schedule.  
(iv)  Draft final report. This report will (a) be submitted 2 months before completion 
of the project, (b) summarize TA activities and results, reporting against the DMF, 
and (c) provide recommendations on any additional steps required to sustain the 
results of the TA. 
(v)  Final report. This report will be submitted by the consultants within 1 month of 
receipt of the comments on the draft final report from the government and ADB, 
and will respond to the comments received.
